Increase in rabies cases in northern Thailand

A doctor from the Department of Disease Control at the 9th Health Office in Taweechai said on the 9th of this month that rabies infections have increased in the northeast of Thailand in recent months, with a total of 74 cases.
So far this year (October 2019 - September 2020) there have been 67 and 7 cases of rabies in Srinagar and Brilam districts in the north of the country.
Everyone has had rabies vaccinations in the past.
The doctor is urging people to get their pets vaccinated against rabies and to avoid contact with the saliva of any animals they suspect may be infected.
Rabies can be transmitted from cats, bats, and other animals to humans.
It is almost 100% fatal once a person is infected and symptoms appear, but vaccination before symptoms appear can prevent death.

Fujitsu Develops System to Prevent Accidents by Leaving Vehicles Behind | Chubu Economic Newspapers: Economic Information for Aichi, Gifu, Mie, and Shizuoka Prefectures

Fujii (headquarters in Chitose City) which manufactures and sells robots and machines for installing electronic parts, has started developing a system to prevent children from being left behind in cars.
The system is set up so that when a sensor is attached to the car and detects human movement, it sends a notification to the phone or chat.
We are currently conducting proof-of-concept testing with our own shuttle vehicles.
Protecting children from the pain of being left behind.

Currently, they are conducting a proof-of-concept experiment with two of their own shuttle vehicles for the child-oriented English conversation after-school program, Terakoya ThanK (Terakoya Sanku), which they operate in the city of Chigasaki.
A human sensing sensor that detects human movement from the temperature difference between the person and the surroundings is installed in three locations on the ceiling of the car.
If the vehicle is turned off and the doors are closed and the system detects movement after a certain amount of time, it will automatically send a warning notification.
By coordinating the state and information of the engine and door, it can prevent misdetection as much as possible.
The alert notification is sent through the cloud.
You can call the number you registered in advance or display it on your computer or smartphone chat.
You can register multiple addresses, and they take care to avoid mistakes like forgetting to register one.
The trial will continue until the end of February.
"During the experiment, we also saw issues with the system's peripherals," said Kamiya Ichikazu, head of the second section of the innovation promotion department.
For example, they were able to pick up various challenges related to school buses, such as creating an environment in which drivers can concentrate on driving.
I'm putting all my strength into expanding the solution."
The development of the anti-abandonment system was triggered by a series of accidents involving abandoned school buses across the country.
From employees with young children, suggestions were made that there was nothing that could be done to protect children's safety.

They decided to develop the technology to utilize the know-how they had gained through their business related to FA (Factory Automation) related business, such as information management using IoT (Internet of Things) and sensors.
Fujitsu's anti-theft system is easy to use.
The sensor can be installed by simply attaching it to the ceiling with a pin.
The fact that it can be easily retrofitted to the shuttle buses lowers the barrier to entry and aims to promote its widespread use.
In the future, we will seek cooperation with kindergartens and nurseries while considering productization.

[Opinion] The construction of the Tohoku Shinkansen line from Tsuruga to Osaka, which was scheduled to begin in 2023, has been postponed, and this is starting to affect urban development in the western part of Fukui Prefecture.
In the city of Shiogama, where a new station is being built, the precise location of the station has not been determined, and urban planning, including the surrounding area, has not been completed.
Planning is likely to take a long time, and an early announcement is needed.
The planned station in Kashima City will be the only new station development west of Tsuruga.
In 1999, the Railway Construction and Transportation Facilities Improvement Support Organization identified JR Tohoku Oshima Station as the center of a roughly 2.5 kilometer radius of major stations.
Details on the station's location and route were to be determined by the winter of 2022.
In Shiogama City, the new Shinkansen-related businesses will be fully developed in the 21st year, with the opening of the Shiogama station in mind.
In the initial budget for the 22nd fiscal year, they are trying to increase the number of businesses and advance the development of the city by announcing the location of new stations.
However, the exact location of the new station has not been revealed yet.
The city has budgeted 3 million yen for this year as a business to consider land use and development concepts based on the location of the new station, but it is likely to be unimplemented.
"Planning a city around a new station takes time because it involves forming a consensus among citizens" (city official).

There is an example of a new station in the suburbs of the prefecture that is not built next to an existing JR station, but it seems that it will take a considerable amount of time to compile the overall concept.
It is feared that if the announcement is delayed, the preparation period before the opening will be shortened, and the impact on the surrounding development will be felt.
The location of the new station is not clear before the extension to the west of Tsuruga.
Last October, Kyoto city's citizens' group on the extension route submitted a petition to the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism, asking for the extension plan to be scrapped.

In Ishikawa Prefecture, there are calls for a reconsideration of the route through the city of Matsuyama, and the prefecture is returning to the original route setting, which has been decided, and the neighboring prefecture is not at all a one-horse race.

While the reception of the postponement of the start of construction by the citizens of Kashima is relatively calm, the fact that the location of the new station is unknown and the opening date is still unclear is also a concern that will affect future opportunities.

Mayor Masazaki plans to continue his efforts to urge the government to open the entire line as soon as possible, but the voices of the local residents who are calling for construction to begin as soon as possible are essential.
The indifference that "the Shinkansen will eventually run through (Tokushima and) west of Tottori" cannot move the national government, neighboring prefectural governments, or municipal governments.
I wish they would keep up the momentum.

The cat-shaped serving robot at the "Ishikawa Salt-Cured Genghis Khan Pork Buns Fukuoka Ekimae Store."
The fact that the family customers liked the cute expressions, etc. = Fukui Prefecture Fukui City Otemachi 2-chome
In the Fukui Prefecture food industry, which is struggling with a shortage of workers, there is a growing trend to introduce cooking robots that deliver food to customers.

In addition to helping to streamline store operations and prevent the spread of the new coronavirus by providing "contactless" customer service, the robot's cute expressions are also popular with family customers.
Restaurant owners and related parties are saying, "It's difficult to secure employees and part-time workers in local restaurants, so meal robot will become more widespread."
“Jingle, jingle, jingle bells, jingle all the way.”
A robot with a cat face on the screen and playing light music glides through the store carrying food.
When they arrive at the table, they say things like "I have your order, Nyanko."
The "Iwase Jingisukan Bon-Tan Fukui Ekimae Store" in Fukui City, Fukui Prefecture, introduced a cat-shaped serving robot in August 2022.
Customers can order food from the table they want to eat at and the robot will bring the food to the table and deliver it to the customer.
It has AI (artificial intelligence) voice functions and responds when a customer touches it, and the cat face on the screen is expressive.
The Bon-Ton Group, which operates the store, has introduced meal-preparation robots at two stores, including this one.

Regarding the reason for the introduction, President Saito said, "The biggest reason is the shortage of manpower," and emphasized that it is part of the productivity improvement through labor-saving and digital transformation (DX).
The ratio of labor costs to sales at stores is usually around 30%, but it can be reduced to 21-22% by introducing this system.

Robots also have a role in collecting plates after customers have finished eating, which leads to more efficient cleaning up, and "it's also good for families and children, and it's good for advertising."
The "Rikka Hoshizaki Fukui Store," which serves grilled meat and hormone soup in Fukui City's Araki Shinhoka-cho, also introduced a meal-serving robot in August 2022.
"We were having trouble recruiting employees and part-time workers," said Yoshimura, president of the Son-san store. "I thought it was absolutely necessary to solve the labor shortage problem."
In the Fukui store, the staff divide the area where they serve meals and the robot delivery range, and use them.
The rental fee for a robot is about the same as one person's salary.
In order to streamline the process, the store is considering using a tablet terminal in addition to robots for the ordering system, and is also considering self-checkout.

According to the Fukui Labor Bureau, in December 2022, the ratio of job vacancies to job seekers for the "customer service" industry, including restaurants, was 6.94, indicating a high shortage of workers.

"There are many inquiries about introducing robots because there is a severe shortage of workers in restaurants in the prefecture due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic," said a representative of the online system that serves as a sales agent for meal-preparation robots (2-chome Kokubo, Takahashi-cho, Fukui City).
"I think it will be even more difficult to secure employees at stores in the suburbs in the future, and I think that meal-serving robots will become more common," said Shimaya.
[Opinion] Kaga Town is creating an ending note and distributing it to residents who wish to receive it.

Last year, when the company published a "funeral handbook" that covered all the necessary procedures and forms, as well as a list of heirs and family trees, many people came to pick it up for themselves.
End-of-life notebooks and pre-death preparation workshops are also held across the prefecture, and it seems that "death work" has become a fixture in the lives of the prefecture's citizens.
The ending note of Owari-machi is 35 pages.
Chapter 5 begins with a review of your life, and you write down your current health status, financial situation, future care needs, end-of-life medical wishes, and funeral and burial preferences.
There are also sections for things you want to do in the rest of your life and messages to the people you care about.
I’m about to break my back writing 35 pages, but I don’t need to fill every page.
What do you want to be remembered for by your family and friends?
The point is to make it clear what the goal is.
There are many different notebooks available in bookstores that are tailored to your needs, and you can start writing anywhere you like.
The term "end of life" was coined in 2009, he said, comparing it to the job search.
Two years later, in 2011, the Great East Japan Earthquake occurred.
Many people have come to realize the reality that death can come suddenly, and there are more people who are preparing for their own end and the end of life.
It's been over 10 years since then.
The new coronavirus pandemic that has swept the world has not yet subsided.
Prices have risen due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and electricity bills have soared to unimaginable prices this winter.
On the other hand, wages have not risen enough to match current inflation, and many people are struggling to make ends meet.
On the other hand, in the past, funeral expenses, nursing expenses, and the management of graves could be shared by siblings and relatives, but nowadays, it is rare to have only one child.
There is also the dilemma that life expectancy has increased significantly compared to the past, but the risk of dementia and need for care increases as people get older.
We should remember that the fact that the end of life is not a temporary phenomenon but a permanent one is also related to the rise of social anxiety.
Either way, no one wants to put their partner or children through too much.
“Dying like a man” is a popular phrase in the ending notes, but it shouldn’t be taken too far.
Wishes and preferences should not be kept secret, but should be discussed with family members and prepared for calmly.

Prime Minister Fukuda (second from right) and Minister of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology Yokokawa Keiko (third from right) pose for a photo with other officials at the elementary school they visited.
Graduation ceremony shows children and teachers don't need to wear masks by default - February 10, Toshima-ku, Tokyo
The Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided on February 10 that children and students should not wear masks at graduation ceremonies.
The headmaster of a large school said, "It's difficult to keep a wide gap between students, and we're struggling with what to do. Some students are worried about taking off their masks."
The topic has also been raised among teachers after reports of mask-wearing at graduation ceremonies.
Meanwhile, one elementary school principal said, "If the government decides, we will not wear it. We can't realistically respond unless we exclude singing."
Some schools in the prefecture are also easing restrictions, allowing students to attend graduation ceremonies and resuming the singing of alma maters, which had been banned.
In the prefecture, the public high schools are scheduled to hold ceremonies in early March, while the public elementary and junior high schools are scheduled to hold ceremonies in mid-March.
Prefectural and municipal education committees are considering waiting for official notification from the Ministry of Education to determine their response.
There were also calls for caution over the Education Ministry's decision to drop its policy of requiring masks to be worn in all school activities from the new academic year in the spring.

"From one day to the next, children are confused by the sudden response of not wearing masks. First, we decided that wearing masks was optional, and then, gradually, more and more children began to take them off. This is a natural progression," said the elementary school principal.

On February 10, the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided that from April, it would not require the use of masks in school education activities, following the government's new guidelines on mask use.
In chorus, physical education, and club activities, masks are not worn.

For the 2022 fiscal year, we will request infection countermeasures in accordance with the current health management manual, and we will inform the education committee and schools on the ground about the precautions to take after April.

Graduation ceremonies at junior high, high schools, and universities will also be held with basic mask-wearing by graduates, faculty, and participating students, provided that ventilation measures are taken.

The NPO organization "Heart-touching Collection Editorial Office" published a book titled "Dear Prime Minister, "The Life-saving Breakwater" from Tohinbo" at their own expense.
"Dear Prime Minister, 'The Lifeline' from the East Shore of Tatsukushi," I published the 10th book with my own money.
The national newspapers have picked up the story and we have had many letters of sympathy from readers.

The purpose of publishing this book is to share the contents of the suicide prevention program, which was created to establish a "good society" by sharing the "social and structural" environmental issues related to suicide in Japan, which were directly heard from the suicidal person.

We have been patrolling the waterfront of Fukui Prefecture's Tsuruoka, known as a suicide hotspot, for 18 years and 10 months to prevent suicide, and we continue to support activities to discover and protect suicidal people and help them get back on their feet.

This is a summary of the issues raised by 784 people (2/6) who have been helped so far, and I am writing to you, Prime Minister, to make the following seven points about the national policies that are needed to prevent suicide.
(1) Suicide prevention activities are “life-saving” activities.
(2) Behind the suicide, there are "human rights violations" piling up.
(3) Suicide victims are victims of social and structural organized crime.
(4) The administration treats people who live outside its jurisdiction as “outsiders” and gives them the cold shoulder.
(5) Mental illnesses like depression are medicated and if you kill yourself it’s treated as an “accident”.

An exhibition titled "People who introduced the flowers of Mt. Takao - A brief history of the study of plants in Mt. Takao" is being held at the Iwaki City General Cultural Property Center in Otake-machi, Hachiman-gun, until the 12th.
The book collects 124 items of materials, including valuable specimens collected by predecessors, and introduces the footprints of predecessors involved in the study of plants in Mt.

The study of plants on Mt. Hakone began with the Russian botanist Karl Johann Maximovich (1827-1891), who arrived in Japan during the late Edo period, and Shigawacho native Sakakawa Nagayoshi (1842-1925), who collected plants under Maximovich's guidance.
Unable to freely walk around the country as a foreigner, Maksimovich asked Suzuki to collect data and continued his research for three years, based in Yokohama and Nagasaki.

Sugawara continued to support Maximo's research after he returned to Japan, which led to the discovery of the "Hime-kokura" cherry blossom, "Nambutou-uchi-so" cherry blossom, and "Miyama-yama-biki-shouma" cherry blossom, which are unique to Mount Fuji.

Later, in 1903 (Meiji 36), modern botanist, Makino Fujitaro (1862-1957), published "Nambutranon" and "Kobanotsumeke" based on the collection of local researchers, and in 1905 (Meiji 38), he discovered and named "Kato-hakobe" after climbing Mt.
From the exhibit materials, it is clear that many researchers have revealed valuable highland plants.

Also, the author introduces the work of Suginuma Masanosuke (1874-1948), who was a school principal in Fukagawa and a botanist who accompanied the survey of natural monuments in 1927, and Tamakawa Shirou (1914-1988), who worked as a teacher at the Tamakawa Town Mountain Museum and also participated in the publication of "Plants of Mt.

"Each plant at Mt. Fuji has a background of research and human connections," said Yoshida, a researcher at the center. "We can trace the connections between researchers from local areas to the whole country."

The exhibition is divided into four chapters, with the first chapter focusing on the faith and history of Mt. Fuji, and the second chapter focusing on the characteristics of Mt. Fuji as seen from geology, based on the research of Heinrich Eduard Neuhaus (1854-1927), a German geologist who laid the foundation for Japanese geology.

"Sakasama Real Estate" opens Okinawa Naha branch office to bring people to the island. They are recruiting landlords. | Society & Economy | Nankai Daily News
Opening event to deepen understanding of "sakasama real estate" through talk sessions, famous town on the 8th day

The Ochiyabu branch office of Sakasama Real Estate, a real estate website service that visualizes the thoughts of people who want to challenge empty houses and empty stores, and collects landlords, held its opening event on the 8th at Etakoku, a well-known community space in Ochiyabu.
The operating company explained the service's outline in a talk session.
"If we can do this in Oki-Nakanoshima, we can create a movement and a flow that will bring people to the island as a whole," said Tsukinoya's representative director, Toshimitsu Takahashi.

Sasakawa Realty works in reverse of the usual real estate process, by revealing the information of those who want to rent and contacting the landlord, and if they agree, they will sign the contract themselves.

As a proof-of-concept experiment to uncover potential vacant homes and build relationships through vacant homes, the company On-Co (headquarters in Mie Prefecture) operates and began service in June 2020.
The opening of the branch office is the ninth in the country.
It is the first in the country on an island.
About 20 people, including staff from O-co and Tsuginoba, the town offices of Wakaba and Shimane, and local residents, participated in the event.

"As the movement to bring people from outside the island has become more active, I thought that if we could utilize empty houses and empty stores, the town and the island would become more lively," said Okubo, explaining the background of the branch office's establishment.
"I want to connect with people who have properties on the island or who want to do something and help them in any way possible to make that happen," he said.

"We need to take care of each and every vacant house, and we need to talk with the locals about what they want to do with the area, who they want to come in and work with, and what they want to base their decisions on," said On-Co's Watanabe Gakushi, pointing out a key aspect of the company's operations.
"The more people connect with each other, the more information will come out," he said, calling for participation in the talks and cooperation in providing information.
